G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as it involves a tort claim with damages exceeding $25,000 exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the defendant resides in this county and the incident giving rise to this action occurred here.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 15.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain his property, including trees and branches overhanging the public way, in a condition that would not present an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully using adjacent public sidewalks.

Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (193.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain his property, including trees and branches overhanging the public way, in a condition that would not present an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully using adjacent public sidewalks.
Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (193.support_reasoning: The case concerns an awning appurtenant to leased premises and primarily addresses landlord–tenant liability and nuisance, not a general duty of a property owner to maintain conditions (like trees or overhanging structures) adjacent to public sidewalks. The court holds that the landlord is not liable where the tenant has control and the premises can be used without becoming a nuisance, and it does not articulate a general duty of the landowner to maintain structures overhanging the public way for the protection of sidewalk users. Thus, it does not support the broad duty proposition stated.
Anderson v. Kopelman, 279 Mass. 140 (193.relevant_excerpt: “It is a general rule that a landlord is not liable to strangers for the consequences to a plaintiff of a nuisance in connection with the building in the possession and control of his tenant, unless the nuisance occasioning the injury existed at the time the premises were demised or the structure was in such condition that it would be likely to become a nuisance in the ordinary and reasonable use of the same…. if the premises can be used by the tenant in the manner intended by the landlord without becoming a nuisance, then the landlord is not liable…”

Fleming v. City of Springfield, 154 Mass.raw_text: Fleming v. City of Springfield, 154 Mass. 520 (1891)
Fleming v. City of Springfield, 154 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain his property, including trees and branches overhanging the public way, in a condition that would not present an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully using adjacent public sidewalks.
Fleming v. City of Springfield, 154 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns a municipality’s duty to use reasonable care in maintaining a public way and a sewer pipe beneath it, not a private landowner’s duty regarding trees or branches overhanging a sidewalk. The court frames the issue as whether the city, which was bound to keep the way in repair, used reasonable care and diligence to prevent a defect in the roadbed caused by a defective sewer-pipe. There is no discussion of trees, vegetation, or overhanging conditions on adjacent private property, so the proposition about such a duty is not supported by this opinion.
Fleming v. City of Springfield, 154 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We also think the case was properly submitted to the jury on the question of the defendant’s liability. The injury was caused by a defect in a way which the defendant was bound to keep in repair. The question was whether the defendant did or did not fail to use reasonable care and diligence in preventing the defect. The accident occurred in consequence of the washing out of the earth under the surface of the road-bed, and that was due to the escape of water through a defective sewer-pipe.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.proposition: Landowners in Massachusetts are responsible for ensuring that trees and appurtenances on their property do not pose foreseeable risks to travelers on adjacent public ways.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landowner’s duty regarding natural accumulations of snow and ice on its own premises, not the duty to maintain trees or other appurtenances so they do not endanger travelers on adjacent public ways. The case holds that landowners are generally not liable for injuries caused by natural accumulations of snow and ice unless their conduct creates an unnatural hazard; it says nothing about roadside trees or conditions affecting public ways. Thus it does not support the stated proposition about responsibility for trees and appurtenances along public ways.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice. Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77, 80 (1992). We indicated in Aylward that ‘under Massachusetts law, landowners are liable only for injuries caused by defects existing on their property and ... the law does not regard the natural accumulation of snow and ice as an actionable property defect….’”

Roman v. Boston, 423 Mass. 629 (1996).proposition: Landowners in Massachusetts are responsible for ensuring that trees and appurtenances on their property do not pose foreseeable risks to travelers on adjacent public ways.
Roman v. Boston, 423 Mass. 629 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns civil service protections for disabled veterans facing demotion or layoff within a police department. It interprets statutory terms like “retained in employment” and “position” under G.L. c. 31; it does not address landowner duties, trees, appurtenances, or risks to travelers on public ways. Therefore it provides no authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts landowner responsibility for trees adjoining public ways.
Roman v. Boston, 423 Mass. 629 (1996).relevant_excerpt: As we said at the outset of this opinion, the issue on appeal is whether the language in G. L. c. 31, § 26, stating that “[a] disabled veteran shall be retained in employment in preference to all other persons, including veterans” provides preferential treatment to disabled veterans in reference to demotion as well as to layoff. We conclude, as did the Superior Court judge and the commission, that the statutory words, “retained in employment” refer to a continuing employer-employee relationship... and does not refer to an employee’s continuation in a particular job or position.

Jones v. Hayden, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).proposition: Landowners in Massachusetts are responsible for ensuring that trees and appurtenances on their property do not pose foreseeable risks to travelers on adjacent public ways.
Jones v. Hayden, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an abutting owner’s obstruction of a sidewalk with hay bales and a truck, and whether that obstruction constituted a public nuisance and was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. It does not address any duty regarding trees or other natural conditions on land, nor a general landowner obligation to ensure that trees and appurtenances do not pose risks to travelers. The case is therefore about sidewalk obstruction and nuisance, not tree-related duties of landowners along public ways.
Jones v. Hayden, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).relevant_excerpt: “In the present case the jury could have found that the roadway was dangerous to travel, that the sidewalk was completely blocked for an unreasonable time, that the obstruction was not reasonably necessary for the transaction of business and unreasonably interfered with the rights of the public, and that the plaintiff was obliged to go into the roadway in order to pass the obstruction. In these circumstances we think that the jury would be warranted in finding that the obstruction constituted a public nuisance.”

Gillis v. Boston, 445 Mass. 59 (2005).proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that the cracked and drooping limb was in a hazardous condition likely to fall and injure passersby, yet failed to inspect, prune, or remove it.
Gillis v. Boston, 445 Mass. 59 (2005).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns juvenile CHINS proceedings, evidentiary hearings, and burdens of proof for extending dispositional orders. It does not involve premises liability, landowner duty, trees, or any issue regarding a defendant’s knowledge of a hazardous limb or failure to inspect, prune, or remove it. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about a defendant’s knowledge of a dangerous tree condition injuring passersby.
Gillis v. Boston, 445 Mass. 59 (2005).relevant_excerpt: In this appeal we decide that, before a judge may extend up to six months a dispositional order with an out-of-home placement arising from an adjudication that a child is in need of services, G. L. c. 119, § 39G, third par., requires the judge to hold an evidentiary hearing and find by a preponderance of the evidence that the purposes of the dispositional order have not been accomplished and that an extension of the order would be reasonably likely to further those purposes.

Hannon v. Waterbury, 106 Mass. 178 (1870.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that the cracked and drooping limb was in a hazardous condition likely to fall and injure passersby, yet failed to inspect, prune, or remove it.
Hannon v. Waterbury, 106 Mass. 178 (1870.case_name: Coleman v. New York & New Haven Railroad Co.
Hannon v. Waterbury, 106 Mass. 178 (1870.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a railroad's use of force in ejecting a trespassing passenger and the allocation of burdens of proof and liability for excessive violence. It does not involve trees, limbs, inspection duties, or hazards to passersby, nor any discussion of a duty to know of or remedy a dangerous physical condition. Therefore it provides no authority for the stated proposition about knowledge of a hazardous cracked limb and failure to inspect, prune, or remove it.
Hannon v. Waterbury, 106 Mass. 178 (1870.relevant_excerpt: "As the action was for excessive violence, which would be unjustifiable, the request applied to such violence, and we do not think it states the law correctly. The plaintiff was not bound to give any notice for the purpose of lessening the effect of unjustifiable violence. It might have been otherwise if they were using reasonable force to expel him, and that force was doing him an injury by aggravating some secret disease. But this is not such a case."

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable care to remove or repair the dangerous condition breached the duty owed to persons such as Plaintiff.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a short concurring opinion by Justice Kaplan discussing the abandonment of common-law status categories (licensee/invitee/trespasser) and critiquing a footnote about trespassers. It does not address, state, or apply a rule about an occupier’s duty to take reasonable care to remove or repair a dangerous condition, nor does it discuss breach by failure to do so. Therefore, this excerpt does not support the specific proposition about defendant’s failure to use reasonable care regarding a dangerous condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was a foreseeable and direct result of Defendant’s breach.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that the harm was foreseeable and that there was a duty of reasonable care, but it does not decide that the harm was a direct (or even actual/proximate) result of the defendant’s breach. The court repeatedly characterizes causation and breach as issues for the jury and reverses summary judgment only on duty, expressly leaving the questions of breach and causal connection unresolved. Thus, the opinion does not establish that the harm to the plaintiff was a direct result of the defendant’s breach; it only holds that such a theory may be submitted to a jury.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … we conclude that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care … we reverse the grant of summary judgment on that count.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence in paroling MacNeil was not the proximate cause of Officer Kent’s injuries as a matter of law, due to intervening and superseding causes. That directly rejects, rather than supports, the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages. The opinion is therefore contrary authority for the claimed proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.relevant_excerpt:
“We also conclude that the Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the plaintiffs’ negligence claims should have been granted because, as a matter of law, the decision of the Massachusetts parole board to release a violent prisoner to a deportation warrant of the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) was not the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries….”

“…there is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision to parole MacNeil…was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries in 1995.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Recovery of costs, interest, and allowable fees pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6C;
